Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of Centromere Assembly in Drosophila

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientific Research:
A hallmark of successful cell division is the accurate segregation of chromosomes to daughter cells during mitosis and meiosis. Understanding how cells mediate this critical event is central to understanding genome stability and, conversely, how its failure contributes to genetic abnormalities in cells and organisms. The centromere is a specialized structure present on all chromosomes that is absolutely essential for chromosome segregation because it provides the physical location for chromosomes to attach to spindle microtubules and be distributed equally to daughter cells. Even though a large number of centromeric components have been identified to date, particularly in humans, only a subset can be identified in the genome of Drosophila melanogaster. Furthermore, increasing new evidence suggests that the centromeres of Drosophila are regulated differently from those of the other eukaryotes analyzed so far. This raises the important question of whether pathways responsible for centromere function are conserved among different organisms. Characterizing this process in Drosophila, a model system that offers powerful cell biology and genetics, will ultimately contribute to a comparative understanding of centromere biology that will provide further insights into this fundamental phenomenon across species. Specifically, this project will identify novel components involved in centromere structure and function and define their role in pathways that mediate maintenance of the centromere through multiple cell divisions. In addition, an exciting new role for the cell cycle in regulating these processes will be further investigated. These goals will be achieved using an alliance of cell biological, molecular and biochemical methodologies to fill major gaps in our knowledge of the intriguing world of chromosome biology.

Broader Impacts:
This project includes ample opportunities for collaborative research exposing undergraduate and graduate students to the interdisciplinary nature of modern scientific investigation. An additional educational goal is to establish a comprehensive hands-on module that exposes students to cutting-edge cell division research including the latest methods in timelapse microscopy. Key outreach efforts are the promulgation of visual tools for the dissemination of knowledge about chromosome segregation and cell division to middle and high school students, teachers and the general public; the participation in initiatives to attract and develop the next generation of female scientists; and the involvement in programs exposing high school students to laboratory research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How cells mediate the accurate transmission of genetic information during cell division is a fundamental question in biology. Errors during chromosome segregation are known to be underlying causes of developmental abnormalities and cancer in humans. An essential component of the process of genome partitioning is the centromere, a structure present on all chromosomes that provides the physical anchor point for the poleward transport of genetic material during mitotic cell regeneration and during the formation of eggs and sperm. In humans, the presence of exactly one centromere is an essential requirement to prevent chromosomal loss, breakage or rearrangement. Under this award, we have employed a diverse toolkit spanning genetics, cell biology and biochemistry to investigate how centromeres are specified, maintained and inherited, using the simple fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster as a model. Like mammals, Drosophila harbors large and and complex centromeres; a distinct advantage of Drosophila is that it offers a number of genetic tools not available in human systems that allow for the study and manipulation of centromeric processes in the context of the whole organism. 

Essential to centromere function is the incorporation of a centromere-specific protein called CENP-A (for Centromere Protein A), whose presence is both necessary and sufficient for centromere function. Despite the critical role for this protein in cell viability, we still know relatively little about how CENP-A is assembled at the centromere, how CENP-A is recognized by its specific assembly factor, and how cells prevent the formation of spurious centromeres. 

Under this NSF award, we have investigated the mechanisms of centromere assembly in Drosophila. A first goal was to elucidate the timing of centromere-recruitment of the main components of the centromere assembly pathway to understand how this pathway is regulated during the cell-cycle. Next, we identified the assembly factor that specifically delivers CENP-A to centromeres, ensuring their stability through many generations. Using protein biochemistry, we isolated the CENP-A assembly complex, and characterized the mechanisms of its recruitment to the centromere. A novel interactor found within this complex allowed us to investigate the interplay between centromere formation and the nucleolus, an essential compartment of the cell nucleus. Another important player in centromere assembly that we isolated in complex with the CENP-A assembly machinery led to the discovery of an important aspect of centromere assembly that involves transcription of centromeric chromatin. Collectively, our work has elucidated many of the molecular underpinnings of the chromosome segregation pathway and its regulation during cell division in a model system, increasing our knowledge of this basic cellular function that is conserved from plants to animals. 

In addition to funding our work on chromosome segregation mechanisms, this award supported several activities with broader impacts. High school students performed experiments and learned about mitosis during summer laboratory immersion programs run yearly by the Mentor Connection at the University of Connecticut.  A new laboratory module for advanced undergraduate and graduate students (Ph.D. and Professional Masters Students) was created and implemented, which explored RNAi and time-lapse microscopy applied to the study of cell division. Undergraduate and graduate students, research assistants and a postdoc from diverse backgrounds were involved in all steps of the research from experimentation to publication.
